Our friend is taking out a loan to help her husband, who has a mechanic's shop where he does various work such as bodywork for all types of cars, but our friend tells us that the majority of their work is bodywork and paint jobs for buses. Do do this work, they have to contract up to two or three skilled workers, whom they pay a salary. Mercedes' husband has done this work for over 20 years.

This loan is for buying paints, grills, welding and other products necessary to do their work. She has been a member of the community bank for 9 years, and she likes it because with the loans she has been able to help her husband in his work.

Her dreams are to continue moving forward and for them to not lack for work.

loans.use: to purchase paints, grills, welding, etc.

loans.name: Andrea Magdalena

texts.es:
En la  parroquia Calderón de la ciudad de Portoviejo,  cada quince días se  reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Desarrollo Femenino. Este lugar se lo conoce por su rica gastronomía y su vegetación, es este lugar la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y comercio en general.

En este lugar vive la señora Andrea, tiene 25 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene tres hijos de 7, 5 y 2 años, los dos mayores  estudian en escuela. El marido es policía. Lleva más de dos años en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque los créditos la sacan de muchos apuros económicos.

Es una ama de casa que para obtener sus propios recursos se dedica a la venta de ropa interior de la marca Leonisa y de productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres días a la semana pero en las mañanas cuando sus hijos están en la escuela ya que en las tardes tiene que ayudarles a hacer sus tareas de la escuela, deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Tiene tres años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, blusas, camisetas, ropa interior y ropa de niños ya que como son  las fiestas de su parroquia quiere vender este tipo de mercadería ya que se venden muy bien en esta época. 

Sus sueños son tener un local y seguir incrementando su negocio.
texts.en:
In the Calderon parish of Portoviejo city, the Desarollo Femenino ["Women's Development"] Communal Bank meets every fifteen days. This region is known for its rich gastronomy and its vegetation. The majority of its inhabitants are farmers and general merchants.

Señora Andrea lives in this region. She is 25 and in a common-law marriage. She and her husband have three children ages 7, 5 and 2. The two oldest children are in school. Her husband is a policeman. She has been a member of the Communal Bank for two years and she likes it because the loans have helped her through many economical tight spots.

She is a housewife who sells Leonisa brand underwear and Yanbal products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfume and women's accessories) to make her own income. She works three days a week, just in the mornings when her children are in school, since she has to help them with their homework in the afternoons. She leaves her products on credit and charges every week. She has done this work for three years and it is going very well for her.

This loan is for the purchase of pants, blouses, shirts, underwear and children's clothing, since it is the holidays in her parish and she wants to sell this kind of merchandise as it sells very well in this season.

Her dreams are to have a store and to continue expanding her business.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, shirts, underwear and children's clothing.

loans.name: Norma

texts.es:
La Sra. Norma pertenece al Banco Comunal “Noche de Luna II” del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 53 años y tiene 5 hijos, sólo 1 hijo de 12 años vive con ella y estudia en el colegio. 
Desde los 25 años de edad empezó a trabajar vendiendo yuca y  plátanos en su casa debido a que su familia tenía necesidades económicas y ella deseaba apoyar a sus padres, al poco tiempo se fue a vivir con su pareja y como estaba acostumbrada a ser independiente económicamente decidió seguir trabajando con la venta de verduras y frutas en un puesto del mercado de su localidad.  Se inició con un capital de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles. Actualmente ella continúa con el mismo negocio y lo ha implementado con otros productos.
Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00 nuevos soles comprará verduras y frutas, como sacos de papas, sacos de cebolla, sacos de tomates, sacos de repollo, sacos de naranjas  y otros.
Norma es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora, anhela progresar e incrementar  su negocio con nuevos productos, está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindar la oportunidad de mantener su negocio y su independencia económica.
texts.en:
Mrs. Norma belongs to the “Noche de Luna II” Communal Bank in the Tarapoto district, in the province and department of San Martín. She is 53, lives with her partner, and has 5 children. Only one of her children, age 12, lives with her and is in school.
Twenty-five years ago she started selling yucca and plantains in her home, as her family had financial needs and she wanted to support her parents. In little time, she moved in with her partner, and because she was accustomed to being economically independent she decided to keep working, selling fruits and vegetables in a local market stall. She started off with a capital of S/. 300 Nuevos Soles. She is currently continuing with the same business and she has added other products. With this loan of S/. 800 Nuevos Soles, she will purchase fruits and vegetables. For example, she will purchase bags of potatoes, bags of onions, bags of tomatoes, bags of cabbage, bags of oranges, and other items.
Norma is a hard-working and enterprising woman. She wants to progress and expand her business with new products. She is very grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for offering her the opportunity to maintain her business and her economic independence.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Hirma

texts.es:
La Sra. Hirma pertenece al Banco Comunal “Noche de Luna II” del Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Está casada, tiene 43 años y 2 hijos, solo uno está a su cargo y estudia aún la primaria. Se inició vendiendo salchipapas (comida al paso) en las afueras de su casa, dejó esta actividad porque su niño se econtraba enfermo, por ello decidió empezar con la venta de sus asados y parrillas (comidas típicas) con un capital inicial de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles para generar sus propios ingresos y poder apoyar económicamente en su hogar. 
Actualmente aumentó la variedad de sus productos, ahora vende juanes, pescados asados a la parrilla (comida típica) y refrescos, y cuenta con clientes fija.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,700.00 nuevos soles comprará  productos en sacos como arroz, azúcar, jabas de huevos, aceitunas en kilos, carnes de pollo en kilos, pescados en kilos, sacos de carbón, también comprará ollas, platos, vasos y cubiertos y de esa manera captar nuevos clientes.
Hirma es una mujer luchadora  y emprendedora,  su sueño es contar con un Restaurante - Pollería, está muy agradecida con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindar la oportunidad a mujeres como ella y así poder hacer realidad sus sueños.
texts.en:
Hirma belongs to the communal bank “Noche de Luna II” ("Moonlit Night II") from the District of Tarapoto, Province and Department of San Martín. She is 43 years old and married with two children. Only one of the children is under her care and still in elementary school.
She started out by selling salchipapas (fried potatoes with hot dog) to passersby outside her house. She quit this business because her son was ill, so she decided to begin selling roasted and grilled meats with a start-up capital of 300 nuevos soles, in order to get an income of her own and provide financial support in her household. She has now increased the variety of her products - she sells juanes, roasted fish, and beverages, and has gotten regular customers.
With this loan of 1.700 nuevos soles she will purchase sacks of supplies such as rice and sugar; crates of eggs; olives, chicken and fish by the kilo; and sacks of charcoal. She will also purchase pots, plates, glasses and cutlery, in order to attract more customers.
Hirma is a fighter and a hardworking woman. Her dream is to own a restaurant with a chicken rotisserie. She is very thankful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for giving women like her an opportunity so she can make their dreams come true.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as rice, sugar, crates of eggs, olives by the kilo and chicken.

loans.name: Zoila Isabel

texts.es:
En la  parroquia Calderón de la ciudad de Portoviejo,  cada quince días se  reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Desarrollo Femenino. Este lugar se lo conoce por su rica gastronomía y su vegetación, es este lugar la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y comercio en general.

La señora Zoila es socia fundadora del Banco comunal, es la secretaria del banco y le gusta porque en el banco le han dado mucho apoyo sobre todo en momentos muy difíciles de su vida. Tiene 62 años de edad, hace varios años enviudo pero  con su difunto esposo tuvieron dos hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad e independientes. Ella en la actualidad vive en la casa de la mamá la cual está muy anciana.

Ella tiene un negocio de venta de ropa junto con su hija, lo administran más que todo su hija ya que ella tiene que hacerse cargo de los cuidados de su mamá, llevan más de tres años con la venta de ropa y nos cuenta que gracias a Dios se vende bastante mercadería, la misma que la compran en Guayaquil cada vez que necesitan, este negocio empezó con uno de los créditos que recibió del banco y que poco a poco lo ha ido aumentando con los créditos posteriores.

Este crédito es para comprar pantalones, camisetas, camisas y ropa de niños.

Sus sueños son seguir incrementando su negocio.
texts.en:
In the Calderón parish in the city of Portoviejo, the members of the Communal Bank "Desarollo Femenino" ("Women's Development") meets every two weeks.  This area is known for its rich cuisine and its vegetation.  In this area, the majority of the people work in agriculture, or in commerce in general.

Señora Zoila is a founding member of the Communal Bank.  She is the secretary of the bank, and enjoys it, as the bank has given her a great deal of support, especially in the most difficult moments of her life.  She is 62 years old, and has been widowed for several years.  She has two children with her deceased husband, who are fully grown and financially independent.  Currently she lives in the house belonging to her mom, who is very old.

She has a business selling clothes with her daughter.  Her daughter does most of the management as Zoila needs to take care of her mom.  She has been selling clothes for more than three years, and tells us that thanks to God she sells sufficient merchandise.  She buys the merchandise in Guayaquil whenever necessary.  She started this business with one of the loans that she received from the bank, and little by little, she has grown it with the subsequent loans.

This loan is to buy trousers, T-shirts, shirts, and children's clothing.  Her dreams are to continue growing her business.

loans.use: to buy trousers, T-shirts, shirts and children's clothing.

loans.name: Tele Alofa

texts.en:
Tele is 48 years of age and is married with six children. Tele owns and operates a business venture, providing dress-making services to local community members.  She has many years of experience in this business. Tele needs a loan of WST 1000 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Tele joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Tele's 1st loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Eseese

texts.en:
Eseese is 32 years of age and married with four children.  Eseese owns and operates a business venture, catching and selling ocean fish.  She has many years of experience in this business.  Eseese needs a loan of 1000 Samoan talas (WST) to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2011, Eseese joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Eseese's first loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Mereane

texts.en:
Mereane is 64 years of age and married. She has five children. Mereane owns & operates a business venture that involves selling baked goods in the local community. She has many years of experience in this business. Mereane needs a loan of WST $1300 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Mereane joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Mereane 's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell.

loans.name: Tomua

texts.en:
Tomua is 48 years of age. She is married and has six children. Tomua owns & operates a business of planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. She has 3 years of experience in this business. Tomua needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.  She plans to use the profits from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand the business.

Tomua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Tomua's 2nd loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Clara María

texts.es:
En la  parroquia Calderón de la ciudad de Portoviejo,  cada quince días se  reúnen las socias del Banco Comunal Desarrollo Femenino. Este lugar se lo conoce por su rica gastronomía y su vegetación, es este lugar la mayoría de sus habitantes se dedican a la agricultura y comercio en general.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Clara, tiene 53 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen dos hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad, uno de ellos  aun vive con ella. Su esposo es jubilado ya que es minusválido.
 
Ella  en su casa además de cuidar a su esposo  tiene un pequeño negocio en el cual vende alimentos y comidas rápidas como empanadas, corviches, sodas, jugos, además de golosinas, ella aprovecha que muy cerca de su casa está ubicada una escuela y que los alumnos en su gran mayoría llegan a comprar sus productos, trabaja todos los días aunque es de lunes a viernes cuando más vende. Tiene 5 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le deja algunas ganancias para seguir adelante, ya que la pensión de su esposo casi no alcanza para los gastos de medicinas y de alimentación.
 
Este crédito es para comprar más golosinas, sodas, jugos, empanadas y otros productos que vende en su local. Este es su tercer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por la ayuda que le da el banco.
 
Sus sueños son seguir adelante y gozar de buena salud.
texts.en:
In the Calderón parish of Portoviejo city, the members of the Communal Bank "Desarrollo Femenino" ("Women's Development") meet every two weeks.  This area is known for its rich cuisine and its vegetation.  The majority of this area's people work in agriculture and commerce in general.

In this location, we meet Señora Clara.  She is 53 years old and is married. She has two children from her marriage who are already grown; one of them still lives with her.  Her husband is retired as he is disabled.

In addition to caring for her husband, she has in her home a small store where she sells foodstuffs and fast food such as empanadas, corviches (a dish made from green plantains and fish), sodas, juices, and also candy.  She takes advantage of the fact that there is a school near her home, and that a large majority of the students come to buy her products.  She works everyday, although she sells most on Mondays through Fridays.

She has been doing this work for five years and it has earned her some income for moving ahead in life, as her husband's pension scarcely covers the costs of medicines and food.

This loan is to buy candy, soda, juice, empanadas, and other products that she sells on her premises.  This is her third lending cycle with the Communal Bank, and she likes it for the help that the bank provides her.  Her dreams are to continue moving ahead in life, and to enjoy good health.

loans.use: to buy candy, soda, juice, empanadas and other products.

loans.name: Hilda Katerine

texts.es:
La Sra. Hilda Katerine pertenece al Banco Comunal “Noche de Luna II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia y Departamento de San Martín. Vive con su pareja, tiene 23 años y no tiene hijos. Desde muy pequeña tuvo afición por los negocios así que por iniciativa propia y junto a su convivente decidió dedicarse a la venta de abarrotes, verduras y otros productos de consumo diario en su propia casa.
Actualmente se encuentra muy animada en su negocio y està satisfecha por haber incrementado sus productos de primera necesidad, tiene muy buena clientela por sus vecinos, familiares, clientes fijos y transeúntes. El nuevo préstamo de PEN 1,500.00 quiere invertir en paquetes de fideos, leche en cajas, sacos de arroz, sacos de azúcar, aceites en litros, conservas de pescado en variedad de marcas, paquetes de gaseosas, jugos, cajas de galletas, cajas de golosinas, verduras, frutas, jabas con huevos y artículos de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Hilda Katerine es una mujer ambiciosa y se siente muy animada a continuar mejorar su negocio asi que contar con una familia. Agradece mucho al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres de desarrollarse en el medio en que desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Hilda Katerine belongs to the “Noche de Luna II” (Moonlit Night II) communal bank in Tarapoto District, San Martín Province and Department. She lives with her partner. She is 23 years old and has no children. From a very young age she had a liking for business, so she decided to sell groceries, vegetables and other products for daily use in the home. She made the decision on her own initiative and together with her partner.

She is currently very excited about the business, and she is satisfied because she has increased the amount of staple goods that she has. Hilda Katerine has a very good customer base made up of her neighbors, relatives, steady customers and passers-by. She wants to invest this new loan of 1,500 nuevos soles in packets of noddles, boxed milk, sacks of rice, sacks of sugar, oil in one-liter containers, several brands of canned fish, soft drinks, juice, boxes of cookies, boxes of sweets, vegetables, fruits, containers of eggs and personal hygiene products so she can continue providing better service to her customers. 

Hilda Katerine is an ambitious woman, and she is very driven to continue improving her business and to start a family. She is very grateful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women to develop the businesses they operate.

loans.use: to buy milk, sacks of rice, canned foods and other products for her store.

loans.name: Los Triunfadores -Chilca Group

texts.es: LA SR DAVID DE 38 AÑOS DE EDAD,CONVIVIENTE CON 01 HIJO MENOR DE EDAD EN ETAPA ESCOLAR , ES SOCIO DE LA ALCANCIA COMUNAL  LOS TRIUNFADORES -CHILCA , SE LE DIO ESTE PRESTAMO  YA  QUE EN EL ANTERIOR CICLO FUE RESPONSABLE  EN SUS CUOTAS   JUNTAMENTE CON TODOS LOS INTEGRANTES QUE CONFORMAN ESTA ALCANCIA COMUNAL . EL SR DAVID ACTUALMENTE  TIENE SU INTERNET, QUE GRACIAS  A ESTE NEGOCIO  PUEDE  BRINDAR ASU FAMILIA  UNA MEJOR CALIDAD DE VIDA . EL SR DAVID SOLICITA ESTE PRESTAMO PARA PODER  COMPRAR MAS  COMPUTADORAS Y ASI PODER OBTENER MAS INGRESOS .EL SR  DAVID QUISIERA PARA EL FUTURO TENER UN LOCAL Y CON EQUIPOS DE ULTIMA TECNOLOGIA .EL SR DAVID SE ENCUENTRA UBICADO EN LA FOTO A LADO IZQUIERDO ,VISTE UNA CASACA COLOR AZUL ,POLO COLOR VERDE Y PANTALON COLOR CREMA
texts.en:
David is 38 years old and has a live-in partner and a young school-age son. He is a member of "Los Triunfadores -Chilca" (The Winners -Chilca) communal bank. He was given this loan because he and all the other members of this communal bank were responsible about making their payments in the previous loan cycle.

David currently has his Internet café, and thanks to this business he can offer his family a better quality of life. David is asking for the loan so he can buy more computers, which will make him able to earn more income. In the future, David would like to have a separate building for the business and the latest generation equipment.

David is on the left side of the photo, wearing a blue jacket, green shirt and cream-colored pants.

loans.use: to buy more equipment for his Internet café.

loans.name: Mayra Alejandra

texts.es:
La señora Mayra Alejandra  desde hace 4 años se dedica al negocio sobre ruedas, en este momento su mayor afición es  la venta de ropa usada, zapatos y accesorios para el hogar. Este negocio es parte de su  fuente de ingresos por tal motivo desea invertir mas en el para seguir prosperando. 

Mayra se ven en la necesidad de pedir un préstamo para comprar ropa de temporada por que en esta época de regreso a clase; mucha gente busca ropa de segunda mano para sus hijos ya que alguna no cuenta con recursos para comprar nueva. Mayra ve la oportunidad para surtir su negocio ya que de esta forma podrá obtener mayores ganancia y así ayudar a su esposo con los gasto del hogar.
texts.en:
For four year, Mayra Alejandra has done business at traveling street markets. At the moment, she is most interested in selling used clothing, shoes and home accessories. This business is part of her sources of income, so she wants to invest more in it to keep doing well.

Mayra needs to ask for a loan to buy seasonal clothing because now, at back-to-school time, many people are looking for secondhand clothing for their children, and some of them do not have the resources to buy new clothes. Mayra sees an opportunity to stock her business so she can have higher earnings and help her husband with household expenses.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es: El joven Oscar es una persona muy responsable y preocupada por el bienestar de sus padres. Hace 6 años los padres de Oscar, cuentan con un negocio denominado “Estanquillo Sarai” en la que ofrece variedad de producto para el consumidor como lo son los refrescos, botanas, tortillas de maíz, leche y más. Este negocio es parte de la  fuente de ingreso que  tiene la familia, aparte la que  gana por maquiladora Oscar,  por lo que pide el apoyo para comprar mayor producto para surtir el negocio. De esta manera Oscar ayudara a sus padres con el negocio para que sea prosperado.
texts.en: Oscar is responsible and concerned with his parents' well-being. Six years ago his parents started a small grocery called Estanquillo Sarai. They sell a variety of products including beverages, snacks, corn tortillas, milk, and more. The business helps support the family, along with Oscar's earnings from working at a factory. Oscar will use the loan to purchase merchandise to supply the business. Oscar hopes to help his parents by making the business more prosperous.

loans.use: purchase merchandise for general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Juan Cruz

texts.es: Juan de 35 años está casado con Judith  tienen 3 hijos que dependen económicamente de ellos; el trabaja 10 horas diarias en una maquiladora de Lunes a Viernes además de tener su negocio familiar establecido desde hace 3 años en las mañanas el negocio lo atiende su esposa y en las tardes y fines de semana el  en el cual los productos que el vende son plumas, libretas, lápices, resistol, papel de regalo y mas. Juan necesita surtir su negocio para este regreso a clases y solicita el apoyo para compra de mercancía y poder surtir las listas escolares de sus clientes.
texts.en: Juan, age 35, is married to Judith. They have 3 children who depend on them. Juan works 10 hours a day in a maquiladora, Monday to Friday. On top of this he has a family business established it three years ago. His wife attends to the store in the mornings, afternoons and on weekends. They sell pens, books, pencils, glue, lined paper and more. Juan needs to stock his business for the back-to-school season, so he is requesting support for the purchase of merchandise so that he can stock up for his customers' back-to-school lists.

loans.use: to buy paper, books, pencils, backpacks, etc.

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
This is Matilde, 49 years old, and a resident of Baseco, Manila, Philippines. Her husband, Timoteo, is a mechanic and they have two children. Matilde, her husband and children manage their household while operating their business. Matilde works hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Matilde operates a motorcycle parts retail business. She buys motorcycle parts and accessories from wholesalers and sells them per item with a profit. Customers are attracted to Matilde's business due to the low selling prices and the many products offered. Her regular customers are neighbors and the local community. Matilde earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in daily sales.

To help her continue business operations, Matilde is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan, which she will use to buy additional motorcycle parts and accessories to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Matilde dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional motorcycle parts and accessories

loans.name: Belenda

texts.en:
Belenda is married with five 5 children. She is 41 years old and lives in Liloan, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental.  For the past 5 years she has been raising pigs to earn a living. She has requested a loan of  35,000 PHP to purchase more pigs.

Belenda has been a member of PMPC for two 2 years. In the future, she hopes to increase her earnings from pig raising so that her total net income is 50,000.

loans.use: to purchase more pigs to raise

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth, 56 years old, is married and has 2 children. She lives in Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. Ruth has been farming for four years. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase fertilizers for her farm. Ruth has been a member of PMPC for four years. In the future,she hopes that she can earn a lot from her farm and business with the help of Paglaum MPC.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is married with three children. She is 32 years old and lives in Delusom, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur.

Daisy sells groceries to earn a living and has had this business for one year. Each month, she earns PHP 10,000 doing this business. She has requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase stock for her general store.

In the future, Daisy hopes that she can provide their financial needs every day.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 32 years old and is a married woman with four children. The oldest child is 11 years old while the youngest is 2. 

Alma is a farmer working in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She primarily grows rice crops to sell. Alma works hard to help provide for her family's needs and send her children to school. She requested a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. Alma hopes to have a stable business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Randy

texts.en:
Randy is married. He is thirty-six years old and lives in Happy Valley, Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur.

Randy sells pigs to earn a living and has had this business for four years. Each month, he earns fifty thousand Philippine pesos (PHP) per harvest doing this type of business. He has requested a loan for 35,000 PHP to purchase feeds for her pigs.

Randy has been a member of PMPC for almost three (3) years. In the future, Randy hopes to earn more income for the success of his business.

loans.use: to purchase feeds for her pigs

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena is married with three children. She is 42 years old and lives in Culo Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. Since getting married, she has been raising pigs to earn a living. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase more pigs to raise. 

Nena has been a member of PMPC for 1 year. In the future, she hopes that she can earn enough from her business so that she can meet her family’s needs.

loans.use: to purchase more pigs to raise

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
59-year-old Cecilia is a married woman with eight children. Her oldest child is 37 years old while the youngest is 18.

Cecilia is a farmer working in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. According to Cecilia, she has been engaged in farming for 40 years. Her income from farming has allowed her to provide for their basic needs and send her children to school.

Cecilia is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. She hopes for this loan to help her achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan is single. He is 39 years old and lives in Lower Salug Daku, Mahayag, Zamboanga del Sur. He has a business selling dried fish to earn a living. He has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase more dried fish to sell. He has been a member of PMPC for 3 years.  In the future, he hopes that he can better support himself financially through the help of PMPC.

loans.use: to purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en:
Ginalyn is 43 years old, she lives in San Carlos, Tukuran, ZDS. She is a married woman with 2 children, her children are all studying. Aside from her income a month, she is engaged in a business in cosmetic sales. She's been doing this business for 22 years and earns 14,000 a month. She has requested a loan for 49,000 to purchase more cosmetics to sell. 

She's been a member in Paglaum MPC since 2008, and used loans 10 times. She has had a good performance in the center.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a hard-working mother who lives happily with her husband and three children in a village. Farming is the main source of their income but due to financial difficulties, Jocelyn engages in cooking and selling food for meals and snacks in her food stall to earn additional income. She has been in this business for almost 10 years earning a net profit of only P8,000 a month.

She aims to improve her business to increase her income to cover all their household expenditures and support the education of their youngest child who is still studying. Due to inadequate capital, she is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy ingredients (vegetables, pork and fish) to be cooked and sold in her food stall. 

She mentioned that she needs to work hard and strive harder to achieve her goals. She hopes that in the future, her business will grow and her youngest child will finish his studies. She believes that nothing is impossible to a person who has strong faith and determination.

loans.use: to buy ingredients (vegetables, pork and fish to be cooked and sold in the food stall.

loans.name: Emaylin

texts.en:
Emaylin is 32 years old and married. She has a 5-year-old child. 

Emaylin is a farmer who tills a piece of land in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. She has been growing rice for four years. Emaylin earns about 5000 PHP per month from farming. Emaylin also sells dried fish to the people in her community. She works hard to support her family and save for her child's future.

Emaylin is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. She hopes to uplift her family's life through her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine earns a living through farming. She is 49 years old and married.

Josephine owns and tills a piece of land in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato, where she and her family also live. Josephine primarily grows rice crops to sell. She said she wakes up early in the morning to attend to her farming duties. Josephine does her best to be a good wife and mother. She wants a happy family.

Josephine is requesting a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to help improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Fresneda

texts.en:
To overcome poverty, Fresneda engages in cooking and selling snacks and meals in their village to help her husband in earning income to cover their family needs. She is 37 years old and has three school-aged children. They plan to continue sending their children to school to give them the best education possible. 

Due to high cost of commodities and school fees, they can't afford to pay for them all. Therefore, Fresneda aims to improve her business to increase her income and finance the school fees of their children and satisfy their daily needs. She wants to ask for additional capital of P10,000 to buy the needed ingredients (spices, pork, fish and vegetables)  to cook and sell in the food stall. She believes that patience and hard work will make it possible for her to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients (spices, pork, fish and vegetables) to cook and sell in the food stall.

location.town: # 22 Jose Abad Santos St., Bayombong, Nueva Vizcay

loans.name: Maria Christine

texts.en:
Maria Christine is 27 years old and married. She has a 7-year-old child. Maria Christine and her family live in Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. Maria Christine's husband works as a farmer and a mechanic.

Maria Christine is also a farmer. She helps her husband till their land and plant rice crops. Maria Christine sells their harvest at her town's market. She earns just enough to buy their basic needs.

Maria Christine is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers, insecticides and seeds. She hopes to earn better and save for her child's future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, insecticides and seeds

loans.name: Kenjahon's Group

texts.en:
Kenjahon is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married to a constructor, whose monthly salary is 4000 soms. Together with her husband she has raised three sons; all the sons work in construction. In order to earn additional money, Kenjahon breeds cattle and then resells them after fattening. In this way she earns an additional 5000 soms for the family budget. 

This profit made it possible for her to repair their house, and she also saved money and celebrated her son’s wedding. With money received from the loan Kenjahon wants to buy feed for cattle. In the future with the profits gained from reselling cattle, she wishes to purchase a car.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for cattle.

loans.name: Maria Fe

texts.en:
Maria Fe is a married woman with three children. She and her family live in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato.

Maria Fe is a farmer. She primarily grows rice crops to sell. Maria Fe's family depends on their farm. Maria Fe and her husband work hard to earn better and provide for the needs in their household.

Maria Fe is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She hopes to have a progressive business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Salamat's Group

texts.en:
Salamat is the leader of this group. She is 74 and unfortunately a widow. She has raised two daughters, both of whom are married and live separately with their families. Salamat is engaged in cattle breeding and started this activity about 50 years ago. In the beginning she purchased a calf and then resold it at good price, thus starting to breed cattle. 

Salamat is a retiree. She receives a monthly pension in the amount of 3750 soms. She also cultivates agricultural products to make additional money for her livelihood. She applied for the loan because she needs financial funds to purchase a calf for breeding and a separator for processing milk. In the future Salamat wants to increase the number of cattle and soon she plans to start repairing a shed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf and a separator for processing milk

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en:
33-year-old Maricar is a farmer who lives in the town of Sto. Niño, South Cotabato with her family. She is married and has 2 children aged 9 and 10. Maricar's husband is also a farmer.

Maricar has been growing and selling rice for 5 years. She earns about 10000 PHP per month from farming. Maricar works hard to provide for her family's financial needs. She requested a loan to purchase fertilizers, seeds and gasoline for her tractor. Maricar is hoping to achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and gasoline for her tractor

loans.name: Phum

texts.en:
Mrs. Phum is a 42 year old married woman who currently lives in Kompong Speu Province. She is married with five children. Four of her children are single and one is married. Three of her children are employed in a variety of jobs making profit. 

Mrs. Phum works as a local farmer. She always grows rice crops and a few kinds of vegetables, and typically earns $2 USD per day. Mrs. Phum would like to request a loan from HKL and Kiva in order to purchase fertilizers and to buy some hogs for breeding. 

Mrs. Phum hopes that with the increase in income she will be able to expand her old house, to support her children with a high level of education, and to enlarge her crop-planting business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and buy some hogs for breeding.

loans.name: Wiguna Merta Group

texts.en:
The Wiguna Merta group is made up of nine women who are neighbors in the same village in Melaya, West Bali.  The group is seeking a loan of Rp 13,500,000 and each member will receive Rp 1,500,000. The group was formed out of these women’s common interest in raising pigs to supplement the family income and out of their interest in education on best practices for pig raising. This is their third loan with MUK.

Ni Ketut, age 40, is the head of the Wiguna Merta group. She is married and has children who are still in school. Her husband earns money as a farmer, but Ni Ketut would like to help support her family with her pig raising business. She will use the loan to buy six local species piglets. She plans to sell the piglets after three months for use as pig roll.  With the increase in household income, she hopes to be able to pay school fees.

loans.use: To buy six local species piglets

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Despite the hardships of life, Marlene wants to continue managing her variety store in their village to supplement her husband's income. She is now 37 years old and has three school-age children. As responsible parents, Marlene and her husband want all of their children to finish their studies and find good jobs someday. 

However, due to financial difficulty they cannot provide for all their children's needs because of the high cost of commodities and school fees. Therefore, Marlene wants to increase her income to supplement her children's financial needs in school. She wants to ask for an additional capital of P10,000 to buy additional stocks of noodles, toothpaste, shampoo, candy, beverages, soap and face powder to sell in the village. She believes that the loan will help a lot to improve her variety store. She dreams that in the future her business will improve and that her children will all graduate from college.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of noodles, toothpaste, shampoo, candy, beverages, soap and face powder to sell in the village

loans.name: Shaiymbubu's Group

texts.en: Shaiymbubu is the leader of this group. She is 58 and, unfortunately, she is a widow. She has raised two daughters and a son; the first daughter works as a confectioner, the second daughter is a teacher and the son is a constructor. In order to earn money to meet daily needs, Shaiymbubu Kyrgyz sews national carpets, cloth and dressmaking supplies. She started this activity 10 years ago with an initial investment of 1,000 soms, and, at the moment, her monthly profit from this activity is 5,000 soms. This profit made her able to save money for purchasing an apartment in Balykchi for her daughter. Shaiymbubu applied for the loan because she needs financial funds to purchase raw materials, which are needed for sewing. In the future, with the profits gained from the business, she wants to save money to purchase a vehicle for her son. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for sewing.

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Mr. Sam, age 40, is a humble man and he now resides in Kompong Speu Province. He is blessed with three single children, one of whom is a domestic laborer and the other two are studying in the local school.
    
Mr. Sam is a domestic rice cultivator. He has had experience in this sector for a long time. He usually plants rice crops on his existing fertile farm and is earning $1 USD a day for use for daily expenses. His wife also works alongside him in the field. Mr. Sam would like to ask for a loan from Kiva in order to buy seeds and fertilizers and other farming materials for supporting him in his farming business. 

Mr. Sam believes that the increase in his income will be used for decoration of his old house, and to sustain his children to finish the high school level. Note that Mr. Sam and his wife's photo was taken in front of their house.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers and other farming materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a determined individual who aims to improve the business she manages. She is 46 years old and separated from her husband due to family conflict and unavoidable circumstances. She lives with her three children in the village. She is engaged in selling dry goods in the market like bags, jewelry, belts and electrical supplies to earn an income and satisfy their basic daily needs. 

Being a single parent, it is difficult for her to send all her children to school. But still she has the strong determination to improve their status of living and give her children a bright future. She aims to improve her business to increase her income for the sake of her children. 

She is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy additional stock of bags, jewelry, belts and electrical supplies to sell in the market. She believes that the loan will help her to improve the business in the future through her patience and hard work.

loans.use: to buy additional bags, jewelry, belts and electrical supplies to sell in the market

loans.name: Aizada's Group

texts.en:
Aizada is the leader of this group. She is 36 and married to a car electrician. Together with her husband, she brings up a daughter and a son. Her daughter studies at school and her son is preschool age (under seven). Aizada works as a cook in the poultry factory, but at the moment, she is on maternity leave. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase building materials to repair the house. In the future, Aizada wants to give her children a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials

loans.name: Ganbat

texts.en:
Mr. Ganbat is 37 years old. He lives with his son, daughter and wife in their own house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He is a taxi driver, and has been running this business for many years. He also works at construction when he has orders for building or decoration. 

Recently, his house and fence became very bad, unstable and uncomfortable to live in. Especially, there is a need to make insulation on the walls, repair the roof and change the window sheets firstly. Likewise, the fence should be renovated and he is planning to rebuild it with brick. 

Therefore, Ganbat is requesting a loan to purchase necessary building materials to make a renovation to his house and fence.

loans.use: To purchase necessary building materials to make a renovation to his house and fence.

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en:
Gantsetseg is a 21-year-old young woman who lives with her family, including her father, mother, a younger sister and a younger brother all together in their own house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

While she could not get an education related to business, Gantsetseg has a sensitivity of successful business activity. Therefore she is planning to open a grocery store beside her house. It is absolutely beneficial and important to her family income. She is going to manage her store with her mother together. Gantsetseg requested a loan to purchase the food commodities necessary to start the activity of the store.

loans.use: to purchase the food commodities necessary to start a store.

loans.name: Jazgul's Group

texts.en: Jazgul is the leader of this group. She is 24 and together with her husband she is bringing up a newborn baby. Two months ago, with an initial investment of 500 soms, Jazgul started to sell Oriflame and Faberlic cosmetics. Her business is running well; at the moment she earns 3000 soms per month. She applied for this loan because she needs additional funds to purchase more cosmetics in order to increase the commodity turnover. In the future, with the profits gained from her sales, Jazgul wants to repair her house. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young and ambitious socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics

loans.name: Mohpari

texts.ru: Мохпари проживает в районе Хуросон. Она замужем. Ей 31 год. Ее муж находится в России. Мохпари имеет среднее образование. Она уже четыре года как занимается животноводством. Она покупает скот в дальнейшем для продажи. На сегодняшний день ее муж помогает ей. Она берет кредит для закупа скота. Мохпари намерена улучшить финансовое положение семьи.
texts.en: Molpari lives the Khuroson region. She is married. She is 31 years old. Her husband is now in Russia. Mohpari has secondary education. She has bee doing animal husbandry for four years now. She buys cattle for future resale. At this time her husband is helping her. She is taking out the loan to buy cattle. Mohpari plans to improve the financial conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Sharapat's Group

texts.en:
Sharapat is the leader of this group. She is 59 and married. Together with her husband, who is a retiree, she has raised two daughters and two sons. All the children are married and live separately with their families.

In order to earn money to meet daily needs, Sharapat breeds livestock and then resells them after fattening. In this way she contributes 3000 soms to the family budget. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future she plans to increase the number of livestock and with the profits gained from trading she wants to improve her living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Andres

texts.en:
Andres is 39 years of age with four school age children. He is a farmer working in the Philippines, where he plants and harvests rice. Andres' wife is a housekeeper. With her determination to help her husband to carry their family out of poverty, she engages herself in a retailing business through which she sells snack foods, powder juice, drinks and breads. 

Through his income from farming, Andres is able to pay for his children's school fees. He wants to gain higher income from his yield in order to save some of it for the preparation of his children for college level education.

Andres wanted to borrow a loan of P25,000 to buy farm inputs like hybrid seeds, fertilizers and to pay for the expenditures of farming. He knows that with the loan he will gain higher income from the business because he will be able to buy and use the exact amount of farm inputs needed.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs like hybrid seeds, fertilizers and to pay for the expenditures of farming.

loans.name: Aisuluu's Group

texts.en:
Aisuluu is the leader of this group. She is 43 and married to a taxi driver. Together with her husband she brings up a son, who is fifteen and studies at school.

Aisuluu works as an office manager in the Rural Consultant Service. At the same time she is engaged in cattle breeding. She started this activity a long time ago. With the profits gained from reselling cattle Aisuluu saved money for purchasing a vehicle.  She applied for the loan because she needs financial funds to purchase feed for cattle. In the future she wishes to purchase an apartment in the center of the city.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for cattle

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en: Pablita is 51 years old. She's married with only two children. She lives in Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. Her children are already working. Pablita has been in a buy and sell business for 13 years. She a dealer of Avon and other beauty products. She earns 5,000 PHP a month just for this business alone. She's been a member in the cooperative for almost four years. Eight times she was able to take a loan from PMPC. She's a good paying member. She wants these loans to be able to purchase more products and to be able to earn more.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a forty-year-old hardworking woman living in her own house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family is vested in her and her desire is to educate her two children. 

For six years, she has been operating a studio, and the business is now at its boom stage. Her major challenge is the evolution of the sector which requires the purchase of modern equipment so that she can remain in business. Her dream is to have a modern photography studio. Susan wants a loan to buy a digital camera and a printer for her studio.

loans.use: To purchase a digital camera and a printer.

loans.name: Kiyomiddin

texts.ru: Киёмиддин проживает в районе Яван. Возраст 29 лет. Женат. Имеет одного ребенка. Его жена домохозяйка. Образование среднее. Киёмиддин занимается торговлей мужской одежды и обуви. Этим видом деятельности он занимается более года. Кредит берет для покупки сезонной спортивной одежды и обуви для продажи. Он хочет увеличить ассортимент своего товара.
texts.en: Kiyomiddin lives in the Yavan Region. He is 29 years old. Married, with one child. His wife is a homemaker. He has secondary education. Kiyomiddin sales men’s clothing and shoes. He has been in this business for over a year. He is taking out a loan in order to buy seasonal sportswear and shoes for resale. He would like to expand his stock.

loans.use: to buy seasonal sportswear and shoes for resale

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is 39 years old and lives in Sebucao, Dumalinao, Zambaonga del Sur. She is married with 3 children.
Jessica works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. She and her husband are working in this business. She has been doing this for 3 years and has requested a loan of PHP 14900 to purchase 10 boxes of fish for her retail business.
Jessica has been a member of PMPC for more than 2 years. In the future, Jessica hopes to have a fish cart to increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase 10 boxes of fish for her retail business

loans.name: Kuuljan's Group

texts.en:
Kuuljan is the leader of this group. She is 46 and she is divorced. She has raised two daughters. The first daughter is in Russia and the second daughter helps her mom with housework. Ten years ago Kuuljan’s father presented her with a sewing machine, and since that time she has been taking orders and sewing Kyrgyz national clothing. In this way she earns about 3,000 soms per month. 

With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and dressmaking supplies which are needed for sewing. In the future Kuuljan wants to see her daughters get married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials.

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace is 36 years old and is a married woman with 4 children. The oldest child is 15 years old.

Mary Grace is a farmer. She grows rice crops and sells her harvest at the market. Aside from farming, Mary Grace also runs a sari-sari (variety) store business. She sells items like canned goods, sugar and vinegar.

Mary Grace has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She hopes that through her businesses, she will be able to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Hilaria

texts.en:
Hilaria is a 51-year-old lady. She is married to Musa, who is 56 years old. They have six children: Fony, 26, and Yane, 24, and also Nini, 22 and Jemris, 20, who are both are studying at a local University. Remi, 18, graduated from Senior High School, and Risat, 16, is studying in Senior High School. Hilaria also adopted a young girl, namely Imel, who is 4 years old. 

Hilaria lives with her family in a simple house. She is responsible for providing for her family, since her husband had a stroke almost a year ago. In order to earn more income Hilaria is running a brick business. She has been involved in the business for two years. It is located at her house. From the business she also assists the youth in her village by employing 4 laborers so they can earn money for themselves. She started this business by using her own capital. 

Hilaria plans to expand this business by purchasing the basic materials such as sand, cement and soil. Unfortunately, she doesn’t have adequate capital to do so. Fortunately, she met TLM’s loan officer who introduced her to TLM’s Individual Lending Program. She is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 10,000,000. She hopes that TLM will approve her loan application.

loans.use: to purchase the basic materials such as sand, cement and soil.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy timber for his workshop.

loans.name: Gulmira's Group

texts.en:
Gulmira is the leader of this group. She is 48 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she has a daughter, who is sixteen and studies at school. Seven years ago with an initial investment of 40,000 soms the family started to breed cattle. They earn their livelihood by reselling cattle after fattening; the monthly profit from this activity is about 5,000 soms. With money received from the loan, Gulmira wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future, with the profits gained from cattle breeding, she wants to save money for purchasing a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Mirzoali

texts.ru: Мирзоали житель района Дангары. Ему 58 лет. Он женат. Его жена домохозяйка. Мирзоали имеет двоих детей. У него средне - специальное образование, шафер. Он предоставляет услугу. Занимается развозкой людей. В этой области он более 25 лет. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины.
texts.en: Mirzoali lives in the Dangara district.  He is 58 years old, married.  His wife is a homemaker.  Mirzoali has two children.  He has a secondary specialized education, as a driver.  He provides a passenger transportation service.  He has been working in this field for over 25 years.  Mirzoali is requesting this loan to make repairs to his car.

loans.use: to repair his car

loans.name: Nestor

texts.en:
Nestor, a father of 3 school-aged children, lives in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. He owns and operates a retail store in their place which consists of daily use merchandise and other necessities.  The store has existed for 4 years already. Nestor is trying his best not to close down business operations because it is through this business that he earns about PHP 4,000 a month.

Nestor is borrowing PHP 5,000 from GDMPC, a cooperative that lends money to finance small-scale entrepreneurs. This amount will be used to purchase daily use commodities to sell at a profit. When this investment works out, according to him, his business will grow even more. Then, the revenue gained from this investment is planned for expanding and improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase daily use commodities to sell.

loans.name: Remy

texts.en:
Remy is a 29-year-old married woman with 2 children, aged 7 and 5. She is a farmer who tills land in the town of Santo Niño, South Cotabato. Remy particularly plants rice crops. She rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. Her family mainly depends on the farm.

She has requested a loan to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers. Remy hopes to have a stable business that will sustain her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies such as seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
Jasmin is a mother of 3 school-age dependents living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She owns a motorcycle for transport. This is a habal-habal, as the folks have called it. It is capable of carrying 2-4 passengers. This business was started 5 years ago and continues serving community members today. A total of about PHP 5,000 a month is generated.

Motorcycle parts may be broken or damaged at any time. To maintain the vehicle in good running condition, Jasmin applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 at GDMPC earlier this year. This will be used to purchase motor tires and accessories to continue pursuing business operations. By having all this fixed, Jasmin hopes to gain more income and to expand the vehicle seating capacity in the future.

loans.use: To purchase motor tires and accessories.

loans.name: Raimon

texts.en:
Raimon is a twenty-three-year-old married man with one child, and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family is vested in him, and his desire is to educate his child up to university. 

He has been in a retail shop business for five years. He acquired initial capital from farming. His hardship is price fluctuation and his vision is a wholesale business in the city. Raimon needs the loan to buy crates of beers and sodas for resale.

loans.use: To buy beer and sodas for resale.

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie is engaged in farming. She has been growing and selling rice for 20 years. Rosalie is 42 years old and is a married woman with a 13-year-old child. Rosalie works hard to support her husband in maintaining their rice farm. She also finds ways to help augment their income, like cooking rice cakes and other delicacies then selling them to the people in her community.

Rosalie is requesting a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and insecticides. She hopes to have a progressive life.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina is a residence of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is married with four school-aged children. Her husband is a farmer and she runs a retail store to earn extra income. It started operating four years ago and continues to exist. The store offers basic need items and other sorts of necessities. From it, she earns 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

As a GDMPC member, Marcelina has enjoyed the privileges granted by the organization to its qualified members. The cooperative allowed her to borrow 5,000 PHP which she will use to purchase rice and corn grits to sell in the community. She hopes that this investment will make sense and help improve her business operations. The revenue will be used to buy fertilizers for the farm cultivated by her spouse and to buy more stock for the store.

loans.use: to purchase rice and corn grits to sell.

loans.name: Chinara's Group

texts.en:
Chinara is a member of this group. She is 34 and married to a builder. Together with her husband, she brings up a son and three daughters. The son and two older daughters study at school and the youngest daughter is preschool age (under seven). Five years ago with an initial investment of 35,000 soms, Chinara started to sell fruits and vegetables in the market. Her business runs well and at the moment, she earns about 13,000 soms per month. With the profits gained from the business, she purchased household appliances and improved the living conditions. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase more fruits and vegetables too sell. In the near future, Chinara plans to save some more money and purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Imee

texts.en:
Imee, a residence of Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, is married. She is taking care of her school-aged child. Her husband works as a driver and she, as a wife, runs a retail store to support the day-to-day needs of the house. This business started two years ago and continues today. All income sources give her a total of PHP 4,000 a month, which she allocates properly.

Earlier in the third quarter of this year, Imee joined GDMPC. An initial loan of PHP 5,000 was used to buy additional grocery items to sell. Now that the store offers assorted merchandise, she expects an increase in sales. The revenue gained from this investment will be used to expand her business to sustain their daily needs.

loans.use: To buy additional grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chicks for poultry farming.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
It is in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines where Marilyn lives. She is 34 years of age and a mother of 4 school-aged dependents. The head of the family works as a driver, and Marilyn is supportive by operating a retail store at home. It has existed for over 7 years. She manages the business well and earns about PHP 5,000 a month.

By joining GDMPC earlier this year, Marilyn was able to borrow PHP 5,000 from said cooperative. The money will be used to obtain more grocery supplies to sell. A fully-packed store attracts many buyers, and she is hopeful of generating a good return from this investment. A part of these earnings is intended to sustain and expand the business as well as to improve the general living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To obtain more grocery supplies to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Being a separated mother of 4 dependents is quite a hard thing to manage. That is what Elizabeth has encountered now in her life. But she strongly stands out, accepts the reality and goes on with life's so much more to offer. It was three years ago when she engaged in running a retail store in her residence located in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. Every month, she earns PHP 5,000.

Earlier this 3rd quarter of the year, Elizabeth became a GDMPC member. Her first loan request is for PHP 5,000, which is intended to acquire daily use commodities to sell. By having all these done, Elizabeth expects to increase sales beginning this day and on days to come. She plans to expand her business range and improve the general living condition of the family.

loans.use: To acquire daily use commodities to sell.

loans.name: Salambogo

texts.en: Salambogo is a thirty-one-year-old married man with four children, and he rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been buying and selling coffee for fifteen years. He started out with 500,000 shillings and now has 7,000,000 shillings as his working capital. His vision is supplying coffee to the East African region and educating his children. Salambogo needs the loan to buy coffee for resale.

loans.use: To buy coffee for resale.

loans.name: Joven

texts.en:
Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, is the community where the whole family of Joven lives. He is 30 years old and married. His wife works as a vendor and Joven works as a metal buyer. He has been roaming around nearby communities buying rusted or used metal products to sell at the highest possible buying rate. Joven usually earns a total of PHP 8,000 a month. He has had this work for 4 years already and continues at the present time.

Joining GDMPC this year is the exact thing that Joven has undertaken. He is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 from the cooperative to procure metal products to sell. The probable revenue to be generated from this business is allotted to adding up capital for metal buying and to improve the general living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To procure metal products to sell.

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is a 42-year-old married woman living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She has 3 school-aged dependents who have assisted her sometimes in the feeding and caring of the animals. The small piggery she is working on at this time commenced 2 years ago. While not the only source of income, Pacita earns a total of about PHP 5,000 a month. 

Pacita joined GDMPC earlier this year to access financial services offered by the organization. She is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase feeding supplies for piglets. She wants to give the best possible nourishment for them so as not to be hesitant in naming the price when selling them. The profit to generate from this investment is planned for buying more piglets to gain more income and improve family's standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase feeding supplies for piglets.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: 30-year-old Mary is a married woman living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her dream is to construct a family house in the near future. Mary owns a retail shop from which she sells African attire and airtime. She has been in this kind of business for five years. Her major challenge has been instability in product prices which affects the demand power of her customers. Mary needs the loan to buy African attire and airtime for resale.

loans.use: To buy African attire and airtime for resale.

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer is married and the father of a school-aged child. He settles for a living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. He has been a fish vendor for over two years, selling different fish varieties every day to nearby communities to earn for the family. At the end of the month, Elmer earns about PHP 4,500, which he divides equally.

This year, Elmer became an official member of GDMPC. He has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to order fish varieties to sell in the local community. He expects to have enough supply for the business, and to allocate an adequate sum of money to sustain his livelihood and expand his business range.

loans.use: To order fish varieties to sell in the local community.

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en:
Sherlita is a 55-year-old married woman with 5 children. The oldest child is 37 and the youngest is 19.

Sherlita has only been in the business of raising hogs for a year. She was helping her husband till their land and grow rice crops before she started raising hogs. She plans to use her loan to purchase pig feeds and vitamins. Each month, she earns about 4,000 PHP by operating the hog-raising business.

In the future, Sherlita hopes to have a better living situation.

loans.use: to purchase pig feeds and vitamins.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy radios and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Aldrin

texts.en:
Aldrin is married and the father of one school-aged child. The family is settling down in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines, where his small piggery is located. He has extra jobs sometimes, but the living resources come primarily from raising these animals. Aldrin has been doing this activity for over two years and is continuing today. He earns a total of about PHP 5.000 a month.

Aldrin joined GDMPC earlier this year to have access to financial services. He is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase swine fattening feeds to augment their growth. When having this done, Aldrin expects to sell them at a higher price, and the profit therein will be used to procure additional piglets to raise and to widen their barred enclosure.

loans.use: To purchase swine fattening feeds to augment their growth.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is from Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She is 30 years old, married and has four school-aged dependents. Three years ago, Gina started a mini-eatery at home to earn a living. She makes different types of foods for sale. Her husband is working as a driver in the community. She earns a total of 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.
